questions.title: Current and potential difference in series circuits

parts.text: In a series circuit, how is the current distributed through the components?
options: It is the same through all components
It depends on the resistance of each component
It is zero after the first component
markScheme: Answer: B – The current is the same at all points in a series circuit

parts.text: Explain why the current is the same at all points in a series circuit.
markScheme: 1 mark: Current is the **rate of flow of charge**
1 mark: Charge is **not lost or gained** in components
1 mark: Therefore the **same charge per second** flows through each component

parts.text: Which two statements about a parallel circuit are correct?
options: The current is the same in all branches
The potential difference is the same across each branch
The total resistance is greater than any individual branch
The current decreases after each branch
markScheme: 1 mark: Same potential difference across each branch

parts.text: Explain why adding an extra branch to a parallel circuit decreases the total resistance of the circuit.
markScheme: 1 mark: Adding a branch provides an **additional path** for current
1 mark: More charge can flow for the same potential difference
1 mark: This increases the **total current** drawn from the supply
1 mark: Since $R = \\frac{V}{I}$, increasing current **reduces total resistance**

parts.text: A lighting circuit in a house is always wired in parallel rather than series. Explain why.
markScheme: 1 mark: Each appliance receives the **same potential difference**
1 mark: Lights operate at their **rated brightness**
1 mark: Components work **independently** of each other
1 mark: If one light fails, **others remain on**
1 mark: Total resistance is **lower**, allowing sufficient current
1 mark: Reasoned explanation linking circuit behaviour to practical use
